issue.title: Missing documentation for creating Ignition-compatible docker containers
Missing documentation for creating Ignition-compatible docker containers

content.raw:
Official documentation is forthcoming, but configuring a cloudsim submission will include choosing each robot name, type, docker image. 

I think the answer for running a controller \(e.g. a particular roslaunch command\) is to put it in the entrypoint for the docker image. You could either try to detect robot name in the entrypoint script or just make a different image for each robot \(probably easier\)
content.html:
Official documentation is forthcoming, but configuring a cloudsim submission will include choosing each robot name, type, docker image.

I think the answer for running a controller (e.g. a particular roslaunch command) is to put it in the entrypoint for the docker image. You could either try to detect robot name in the entrypoint script or just make a different image for each robot (probably easier)

issue.title: Missing documentation for creating Ignition-compatible docker containers

content.raw:
I realize that since we are not even able to move a robot \([#103](#!/osrf/subt/issues/103/x1-and-x2-basic-motion)\) this might still seem like a low priority question but we really need to know how the docker image we upload interacts with the simulation in the cloud. Our expectation is that the simulation runs outside of our docker container. We also expect there is going to be one docker container per robot controller \(it has been mentioned in comments to other issues\). It would be extremely useful being able to recreate this multicontainer setup locally to properly test everything. Can you please clarify this as soon as possible?

If our expectations are correct, can you please publish the docker image for running the simulation server \(ie. running rosmaster that we can connect to over the network\)? Can this docker image be prebuilt, tested and ready to run? I think it is not necessary to drag everyone through the installation of everything ign related while we can just install ROS libraries into our controller image and use your prebuilt image to run the simulation server.

It also neatly solves the issue [#95](#!/osrf/subt/issues/95/problems-stopping-all-processes-associated) because we just shutdown your container and be done with it. You get the time you need to work on the issues and we get something to work with like right now. Win-win.
content.html:
I realize that since we are not even able to move a robot (#103) this might still seem like a low priority question but we really need to know how the docker image we upload interacts with the simulation in the cloud. Our expectation is that the simulation runs outside of our docker container. We also expect there is going to be one docker container per robot controller (it has been mentioned in comments to other issues). It would be extremely useful being able to recreate this multicontainer setup locally to properly test everything. Can you please clarify this as soon as possible?

If our expectations are correct, can you please publish the docker image for running the simulation server (ie. running rosmaster that we can connect to over the network)? Can this docker image be prebuilt, tested and ready to run? I think it is not necessary to drag everyone through the installation of everything ign related while we can just install ROS libraries into our controller image and use your prebuilt image to run the simulation server.

It also neatly solves the issue #95 because we just shutdown your container and be done with it. You get the time you need to work on the issues and we get something to work with like right now. Win-win.

issue.title: Missing documentation for creating Ignition-compatible docker containers

content.raw: [This document](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture) should help to answer some of the questions. Right now, we're working on a setup that emulates the CloudSim environment on a single local computer so competitors can test and debug their solution locally.
content.html: This document should help to answer some of the questions. Right now, we're working on a setup that emulates the CloudSim environment on a single local computer so competitors can test and debug their solution locally.

issue.title: Missing documentation for creating Ignition-compatible docker containers

content.raw:
Thanks Alfredo for the scheme - that surely helps to understand the planned concept. :slight_smile: 

What is not clear to me yet, is if there is going to be way how to access internal logfiles of each robot AFTER the simulation run? As an example are camera images which were used for artifact report. They are crucial part of development process. Thanks Martin
content.html:
Thanks Alfredo for the scheme - that surely helps to understand the planned concept.

What is not clear to me yet, is if there is going to be way how to access internal logfiles of each robot AFTER the simulation run? As an example are camera images which were used for artifact report. They are crucial part of development process. Thanks Martin

issue.title: Missing documentation for creating Ignition-compatible docker containers

content.raw:
I am currently getting the error “Error #3013: Invalid value in field.” whenever trying to submit an image to the Virtual Stix cloudsim.  I have read and followed the instructions here: [#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/qual\_cloudsim](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/qual_cloudsim) where the image address obtained is the same for both subt\_docker.bash and subt\_docker\_uri.bash calls for being built/referenced so I don’t think it’s a problem with the link.  I also have created an image a few different ways with/without an ENTRYPOINT and I still get the same error so I don’t think it’s a problem with my image.

My input to the form is as follows:

Name: Trial01

Circuit: Virtual Stix

Robot name: alpha

Docker Image URL: <aws stuff>.amazonaws.com/subt/<team\_name>:<tag>

Robot type: X1 Config 4

I then press “Add” for the robot, it’s added and shown below then I press “Submit” and get the “Error #3013: Invalid value in field.”  Is it expecting \(and thus requiring\) more than one robot?  Is my link bad?  Is this part ready?
content.html:
I am currently getting the error “Error #3013: Invalid value in field.” whenever trying to submit an image to the Virtual Stix cloudsim. I have read and followed the instructions here: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/qual_cloudsim where the image address obtained is the same for both subt_docker.bash and subt_docker_uri.bash calls for being built/referenced so I don’t think it’s a problem with the link. I also have created an image a few different ways with/without an ENTRYPOINT and I still get the same error so I don’t think it’s a problem with my image.

My input to the form is as follows:

Name: Trial01

Circuit: Virtual Stix

Robot name: alpha

Docker Image URL: <aws stuff>.amazonaws.com/subt/<team_name>:<tag>;

Robot type: X1 Config 4

I then press “Add” for the robot, it’s added and shown below then I press “Submit” and get the “Error #3013: Invalid value in field.” Is it expecting (and thus requiring) more than one robot? Is my link bad? Is this part ready?
